awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Prediction of multiscale emergent dynamics in decentralized cell populations
awd_abstract_narration:
PI: Bagheri, Neda
Proposal No: 1653315

The proposed work will develop computational approaches to predict dynamics of cell populations. Signaling present within a cell and from cell-to-cell will be mathematically modeled to predict emergence in cellular, tissue and tumor microenvironments, with special emphasis on breast cancerous tumors. Additionally, STEM concepts will be introduced to young and diverse audiences through children?s textbooks with hands-on exercises that highlight the contribution of women and underrepresented minorities to the field.

Advances in technology offer remarkable insights into individual cell signaling and function; their constraints limit investigation of how these cells cooperate within the microenvironment to produce robust emergent cell population dynamics. Computational approaches can be used to fill gaps in knowledge but biological complexity demands increasingly sophisticated frameworks, and our field has yet to develop a fully integrated, multi-scale, multiclass heterogeneous model that can be adapted to countless contexts to predict emergence of cell populations. This project offers such a framework where large-scale dynamics arise from individual autonomous cell decisions through a predictive agent based model. Our model includes intra-and intercellular signaling, heterogeneity of cell types (healthy and cancer cells) and states (e.g., proliferative, quiescent, migratory, and others), metabolism of nutrients, and physical orientation and constraints. It will be one of the first models to integrate these biochemical and physical responses in a single framework to predict emergence in the microenvironment. Given its generalizable and flexible framework, people from all disciplines can find familiarity in emergence, providing invaluable cross-disciplinary opportunities for discussion and research. The accessibility of such a model will also enable advanced principles on complexity and emergence to be woven into educational material. In addition to curriculum development, STEM concepts will be introduced to young and diverse audiences through children?s textbooks (with hands-on exercises) that highlight the contribution of women and underrepresented minorities to the field. This effort will involve the collaboration of students from STEM and non-STEM fields to advance best practices of teaching and learning for youth. By making STEM topics more familiar and less procedural, the next generation of students will be guided with a basic understanding of computer science, machine learning, complexity, and biology. This CAREER proposal supports multi-disciplinary research opportunities to catalyze understanding of complex biological systems and facilitate integration of related findings into accessible stories and demonstrations distributed to broad audiences.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
This career award served as a catalyst for the development of a modular and adaptable agent-based model (ABM) designed to elucidate complex cell population dynamics. ABMs---originally popularized in the mid to late 1900s---are instrumental in predicting the cooperative and/or competitive behavior of individual autonomous agents (or players) within defined environments. In our research, we extended the application of ABMs to investigate cell populations in solid tumor contexts, creating a means to simulate how cell populations evolve in vivo where agents represent individual cells.

Our model stands out due to its notable complexity, encompassing various cell agent types (e.g., healthy tissue, cancer, immune) and a wide range of potential states for each cell agent (e.g., proliferative, migratory, stimulatory, toxic, inactive, …). Additionally, our model considers the changing architecture and function of the environment, including vascular remodeling. What distinguishes our model further is the dynamic decision-making process of cell agents; instead of static rules, each cell agent's action is based on probabilities that are anchored to the agent’s subcellular protein and metabolic state as well as local protein signals and nutrients. In this way, we have developed a uniquely multiscale model---spanning subcellular to tissue level dynamics---that closely mirrors cell populations in vivo.

Extensive analysis of our model has allowed us to characterize multilateral regulation among diverse cell populations (or among different/competing cell agents types), and between cell populations and their resident vasculature. Notably, our model unravels the critical regulatory relationship between cells and their microenvironment, providing a foundational understanding essential for basic science, engineering, and medicine. The impact of this modeling framework extends to various research projects, many of which have been spearheaded by underrepresented graduate students in STEM. These projects encompass diverse areas such as analyzing vascular architecture and function in tumor microenvironments, designing CAR T-cells for solid tumors, investigating the information content of in situ tumor biopsies, and emulating costly simulations.

The success of this career award has led to numerous publications (https://bagherilab.com) and has resonated within the computational biology community and has reached across diverse disciplines of biology, including developmental biology, stem cell biology, and plant biology. Committed to transparency and open science, my lab has dedicated significant effort to making all our models, algorithms, and data publicly accessible, accompanied by comprehensive documentation and user guides. You are invited to explore and utilizes these resources: https://github.com/bagherilab.


Last Modified: 01/03/2024
Modified by: Neda Bagheri
